VIDEO: Trojico so evakuirali s silo, v mestu še najmanj 200 neeksplodiranih peklenskih strojev
V Mariboru včeraj uspešno deaktivirali tudi drugo bombo. V mestu naj bi bilo še najmanj 200 neeksplodiranih peklenskih strojev.
04 Nov 2019, 07:15 by Aleš Andlovič



Uspešno so jo deaktivirali. FOTO: Oste Bakal



Mariborske ulice so bile zaprte že od zgodnjega jutra. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič



Gasilci so trkali na vrata, tudi tistim, ki niso hoteli iz svojih stanovanj. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič



Jama ob Plinarniški ulici, v katero so položili bombo, preden so začeli odvijati vžigalnik. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič



Petsto kilogramov težko bombo so našli na nasipu ob železniški progi. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič



V dorani Tabor se je zbralo manj ljudi kot v četrtek, niti hišnih ljubljenčkov ni bilo. FOTO: Oste Bakal


MARIBOR – Enajst minut dlje kot minuli četrtek, ko so pri Europarku deaktivirali prvo bombo iz druge svetovne vojne, je pri Mariborčanih včeraj trajala negotovost glede druge, večje in težje, najdene v Melju pri železniškem mostu čez Dravo.


V dorani Tabor se je zbralo manj ljudi kot v četrtek, niti hišnih ljubljenčkov ni bilo. FOTO: Oste Bakal

Natančno 109 minut po razglasitvi splošne nevarnosti, ki so jo nekaj sekund čez nedeljsko poldne napovedale sirene, je sledilo olajšanje. »Uspelo jim je odviti mehanski vžigalnik,« je kmalu po 13. uri dejal Miran Šadl z mariborske policijske uprave. 
Odvili so vžigalnik
Kot so po koncu akcije, ki je potekala po načrtih, dejali pirotehniki, so slabih 36 minut po razglasitvi splošne nevarnosti 500 kilogramov težko bombo spravili v posebej pripravljeno jamo ob Plinarniški ulici. Točno 35 minut kasneje je sledila odrešilna novica, da je pirotehnikom uspelo odviti sprednji mehanski vžigalnik.Brez vžigalnika nenevarno bombo z eksplozivom so nato naložili na tovornjak uprave za zaščito in reševanje in jo odpeljali na uro slikanja s predstavniki sedme sile, v jami pa je ostal vžigalnik. Štiriintrideset minut čez eno uro je sledil pok, iz jame ob železniški progi se je skadil črn dim. Šlo je za nadzorovano uničenje vžigalnika, kar je povsem običajno pri tovrstnih posegih.


Petsto kilogramov težko bombo so našli na nasipu ob železniški progi. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič

Že od zgodnjih jutranjih ur je bil Maribor podoben mestu duhov: ulice so bile prazne, tisti ljudje, ki jih je bilo videti, so se odpravljali na kosilo ali obisk k prijateljem in znancem, da bi ubežali preteči nevarnosti. »Vsi niso hoteli prostovoljno zapustiti svojih domov,« nam je dejala bralka.Informacijo smo preverili pri policistih in dobili potrditev, da so morali trojico, ki je nasprotovala evakuaciji, prisilno odpeljati z njihovih domov. Kot smo izvedeli, naj bi šlo za starejše osebe, ki so omejeno gibalno sposobne in niso hotele nikamor, zato so jih namestili v dvorani Tabor. Tam je bilo včeraj sicer manj ljudi od pričakovanih, saj je moralo svoje domove zapustiti dobrih tisoč Mariborčanov.


Jama ob Plinarniški ulici, v katero so položili bombo, preden so začeli odvijati vžigalnik. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič

Med tistimi, ki so morali prisilno v dvorano Tabor, je bila tudi nepokretna ženska, ki je njena hči Andreja Županič ni mogla prepričati, da bi prostovoljno zapustila dom. »Mama je nepokretna in ni hotela zapustiti stanovanja. Vztrajala je, da ne bo šla nikamor. Že gasilcem sem namignila, da zna zaradi tega nastati težava, zato so v 'pogajanja' vključili policiste. A sprva niti to ni pomagalo, tudi njim se je na začetku malo upirala, na koncu pa morala popustiti in so ponjo prišli reševalci,« je obupana razlagala Andreja. 
Dva načrta
Pirotehniki so se dobro pripravili na včerajšnjo akcijo. Izdelali so dva načrta, kako se lotiti uničenja bombe, v kateri je bilo še 243 kilogramov eksploziva. Na bombi, ki je verjetno med bombardiranjem padla na železniške tire, je bil nameščen le še prednji vžigalnik, zadnjega je ob prelomu odtrgalo.


Gasilci so trkali na vrata, tudi tistim, ki niso hoteli iz svojih stanovanj. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič

Prvotni in zaželeni plan pirotehnika Saša Turnška je bil, da odvijejo vžigalnik in ga kasneje uničijo, toda možnosti, da se bo vžigalnik dal odviti, so bile 50:50. Pirotehniki imeli od četrtka veliko časa, da so še nekoliko priredili orodje za odvijanje vžigalnika, da se je popolnoma prilegal tistemu na 500 kilogramov težki bombi. Če bi se načrt z odvijanjem vžigalnika izjalovil, so imeli rezervni načrt. Bombo bi morali kontrolirano sežgati. K sreči jim tega ni bilo treba storiti.»Vžigalnik se je nahajal na sprednjem delu bombe in ga nismo popolnoma uničili, ampak le del. Bilo ga je težje odviti kot pri četrtkovi deaktivaciji. Bomba je padla na tire, zato se je poškodoval vžigalnik, bil je miren in nabit,« je po uspešni akciji dejal Bojan Kopač, pripadnik Državne enote za neeksplodirana ubojna sredstva. Dodal je, da je šlo za klasičen mehanski vžigalnik. Nevarnost je bila največja pri odvijanju, saj takrat niti strokovnjak ne ve natančno, do kam se bo kaj premaknilo.


Mariborske ulice so bile zaprte že od zgodnjega jutra. FOTO: Aleš Andlovič

»Če primerjamo današnjo bombo in tisto iz Vurberka, je bila v Vurberku zagotovo zahtevnejša. Danes (včeraj, op. p.) pa je bila zadeva zahtevnejša z vidika evakuacije,« je poudaril Kopač. Uspešno deaktivirana bomba je imela 250 kilogramov eksploziva, in če bi eksplodirala, bi na tem mestu, na višini, imela izredni udarni val v radiju vsaj 200 metrov. Pokalo bi steklo, fasade, ocenjujejo strokovnjaki. 
Porušenega skoraj pol mesta
Maribor je bil v drugi svetovni vojni eno najbolj bombardiranih mest na območju Jugoslavije. V obdobju od januarja 1944 do aprila 1945 je doživel 22 hudih zračnih napadov, v katerih so zavezniška letala na mesto odvrgla 15.795 bomb, skupno težkih 4750 ton, ki so popolnoma porušile ali poškodovale 47 odstotkov zgradb.V bombardiranju je bilo ubitih 483 ljudi, med njimi 60 otrok. Po ocenah strokovnjakov je na Maribor in okolico padlo 250 zavezniških bomb, ki se niso aktivirale. V preteklih letih so na širšem območju v bližini Drave našli (le) dobrih deset odstotkov teh neeksplodiranih ubojnih sredstev, neeksplodiranih peklenskih strojev naj bi bilo na območju mesta pod Pohorjem še najmanj 200.
eksploziva je bilo v bombi.
Obstajala naj bi območja, kjer so te bombe eksplodirale, ni pa kart oziroma zemljevidov, ki bi prikazovali še neaktivirane bombe. Prvo območje tveganja je železniška postaja, drugo Studenci in tretje Tezno, ki je bilo takrat najbolj bombardirano. Zaradi preteče nevarnosti bodo na mariborski občini pripravili spremembo odloka, ki bo določal, da bo treba na območju tveganja pri gradbenih delih izvesti predhodne raziskave. Gradbeni delavci, ki izvajajo izkope, so v tem primeru najbolj izpostavljeni nevarnosti.

Yesterday in Maribor successfully deactivated another bomb. The city is expected to have at least 200 unexploded inferno machines.

MARIBOR - Eleven minutes longer than last Thursday, when the first WWII bomb was deactivated at Europark, uncertainty about the second, larger and heavier one found at Melje near the railway bridge over the Drava lasted yesterday.


There were fewer people in the Doran camp than on Thursday, and there were no pets. PHOTO: Oste Bakal

Exactly 109 minutes after the announcement of the general danger announced by sirens a few seconds later at noon Sunday, relief followed. "They managed to unscrew a mechanical lighter," said Miran Šadl of the Maribor Police Directorate shortly after 1pm.
They unscrewed the lighter
As the pyrotechnics said after the end of the campaign, 36 minutes after the announcement of the general danger of 500 kilograms, the heavy bomb was dropped into a specially prepared cave near Plinarnica Street. Exactly 35 minutes later, the breaking news came that the pyrotechnics had succeeded in unscrewing the front mechanical lighter. Without the lighter, a dangerous explosive bomb was then loaded onto the truck of the Protection and Rescue Directorate and taken to an hour of imaging with representatives of the Seventh Force, and remained in the cave. lighter. Thirty-four minutes later, an explosion followed, black smoke billowing from the cave along the railway line. It was the controlled destruction of a lighter, which is quite common in such operations.


A five-hundred-pound heavy bomb was found on an embankment along the railway line. PHOTO: Ales Andlovich

Ever since the early hours of the morning, Maribor has been like a ghost town: the streets were empty, those people who were seen going out for lunch or visiting friends and acquaintances to escape the dangers. "Not everyone wanted to leave their homes voluntarily," the reader told us. We checked the information with police officers and received confirmation that the three who opposed the evacuation had to be forcibly removed from their homes. As we learned, they were elderly people with limited mobility and did not want to go anywhere, so they were placed in Tabor Hall. Yesterday, there were fewer people than expected, as more than a thousand Mariborans had to leave their homes.


The cave along Plinarnica Street where they put a bomb in before they started to unload the lighter. PHOTO: Ales Andlovich

Among those who had to forcibly enter the Tabor Hall was an immovable woman who could not be persuaded by her daughter Andreja Zupanic to leave the home voluntarily. “My mother is immobile and she did not want to leave the apartment. She insisted she would not go anywhere. I had already hinted to firefighters that this could be a problem, so police were involved in the 'negotiations'. But at first it didn't help either, she also resisted them a little at first, but eventually had to relent and rescuers came to her, ”Andrei said desperately.
Two plans
Pyrotechnics were well prepared for yesterday's action. They made two plans to deal with the destruction of a bomb containing 243 kilograms of explosives. The bomb, which probably fell on the rail tracks during the bombing, only had a front lighter installed, the last one being torn off at break.


Firefighters were knocking on doors, even to those who did not want out of their apartments. PHOTO: Ales Andlovich

The original and desirable plan for Sasha Turnšek's pyrotechnics was to unscrew the lighter and destroy it later, but the chances were that the lighter could be unwound were 50:50. Pyrotechnics have had plenty of time since Thursday to tweak the lighter's unscrewing tool a bit to fit the one on the 500-pound bomb. If the plan had failed with the unlocking of the lighter, they had a backup plan. The bombs should be controlled incinerated. Thankfully they didn't have to do that. "The lighter was located at the front of the bomb and we didn't completely destroy it, but only a part. It was harder to unscrew than Thursday's deactivation. The bomb fell on the rails, so the lighter was damaged, it was calm and charged, "said Bojan Kopac, a member of the National Explosive Ordnance Unit after the successful campaign. He added that it was a classic mechanical lighter. The danger was greatest when unscrewing, because even then the expert does not know exactly where anything will go.


The streets of Maribor have been closed since early morning. PHOTO: Ales Andlovich

“Comparing today's bomb with that of Wurberk, it was definitely more challenging in Wurberk. Today (yesterday, op. P.), The matter was more demanding in terms of evacuation, "Kopač emphasized. The successfully deactivated bomb had 250 pounds of explosives, and if it exploded, it would have had an extraordinary shock wave in the radius of at least 200 meters at that point, at altitude. The cup would be glass, facades, experts estimate.
Nearly half the city demolished
Maribor was one of the most bombed cities in Yugoslavia during World War II. Between January 1944 and April 1945, it suffered 22 serious air strikes in which Allied aircraft dropped 15,795 bombs on the site, totaling 4,750 tons, completely destroying or damaging 47 percent of buildings. 483 people were killed in the bombing, 60 children. According to experts, 250 Allied bombs have fallen on Maribor and its surroundings, which have not been activated. In the past years, more than ten percent of these unexploded ordnance and unexploded ordnance have been found in the wider area near the Drava, with at least 200 more in the area below Pohorje.
